attributes.alt: Book cover for Duck on a Bike by David Shannon. The cover art shows a duck riding a bicycle.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through making animal sounds, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Why did Duck ride the bike?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of story words.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Invite children to look at pictures of different objects, identify the objects, and then say the beginning sound.
Help children sort the cards into two groups:
What can happen when we try  something new?
Find a book about an activity that you would like to try.
Pretend you are going on  an adventure. How will you  get ready?
Sort toys into those that make sounds and those that don’t  make sounds.
Write a story about an adventure you would like to take.
What materials can you use to build a bike? How will you make its tires?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Use blocks to make a farm for the animals in the story.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder  to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior
Exercise good habits of personal safety.
Have children look at picture cards and match people’s behavior to how they might be feeling.
Challenge children to think of strategies for managing their own feelings.
What can happen when we try something new?
Find a book that shows something you would like to try.
Pretend you are riding a bike for the first time.
Show five animals that talked to Duck. How do you know there are five?
Write about your behavior when you feel happy.
Draw a bike that you would like to ride.
What letter is at the beginning of your name? What sound does the  letter make?
Can you build a place where  you can park a bike?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill and introduce vocabulary
What are the animals feeling when they see Duck riding a bike?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use a growing number of story words.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Have children look at pictures and identify what the children are doing. Challenge them to identify the past tense word for that action.
Discuss past tense words for actions children might have done today.
What can happen when we try something new?
Read the book by placing your finger under the words.
Can you show me how you look when you’re feeling excited?
Can you compare the size of two animals in the story?
Can you write about doing something for the first time?
How do you feel when you try something new? Draw a picture of a time when you tried something new.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words
Can you build a home for a horse? What materials will  you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background on good habits of nutrition and exercise and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
What can happen when we try something new?
Understand and use a growing number of story words.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Exercise good habits of personal safety.
Master basic skills of running, climbing, jumping,  and pedaling.
Challenge children to identify healthy and unhealthy foods.
Discuss eating foods with added sugar in moderation.
Discuss healthy and unhealthy ways of preparing food.
What can happen when we try something new?
Can you find books with pictures of healthy foods?
How would you walk if you were a duck? A horse? A chicken? Which would walk the fastest?
Put those animals in order from slowest to fastest.
Write about Duck. What did he do in the book?
Use clay or paper to make  a home for chickens.
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word
Try using materials to make  a healthy meal.

elements.text: Use Circle to introduce vocabulary words
What happened to Duck when he tried something new?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Show motivation to communicate; Use appropriate tone of voice.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, mood, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Write about a time when you tried something new. What happened?
Save children’s drawings to display next week.
What can happen when we try something new?
If you wrote your own book about trying new things, what would you put in it?
Pretend that you are riding  a bicycle. Show how you  would move.
Which parts of the bicycle make it move? Can you draw them?
Create a story about how you would train to ride a bike.
Can you draw a place where you might ride a bike?
What is the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
? Can you say other words that start with that sound?
How could you build wheels for a bike? What materials will you use? What shape will you make?

Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Are able to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently.
Demonstrate an understanding that others  have perspectives and feelings that are different than their own.
Practice good habits of personal safety.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Can produce a word that begins  with the same sound as a  given pair of words.
Demonstrate understanding of print directionality including left to right and top to bottom.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Identify good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Practice good habits of personal safety.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation (may not yet coordinate consistently with a partner).
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use art as a form of self-expression and representation.
